sections.title: Nicanor's Plot Against Judas and the Sabbath

verses.text: When Nicanor learned that Judas and his followers were in the region of Samaria, he decided to attack them on the day of rest.
verses.comment: Nicanor's choice to attack on the Sabbath highlights the ongoing conflict between pagan rulers and the Jewish people's faithfulness to the Lord's commandments. The Sabbath represented a covenant sign between God and His people (cf. Ex. 31:12-17).
verses.sectionHeader: Nicanor's Plot Against Judas and the Sabbath

verses.text: Those Jews who were compelled to follow him said, 'Do not slaughter them in such a cruel and savage way; show respect for the day that has been honored and sanctified above all others.'
verses.comment: The Jewish people here appeal to the sanctity of the Sabbath, a concept foundational for understanding the gravity of God’s law and its binding nature.

verses.text: But he asked, 'Is there a Lord in the heavens who commanded the keeping of the seventh day?'
verses.comment: Nicanor's question betrays pagan ignorance of Israel’s faith in the living God and the revealed Law, echoing the attitude of scoffers in the Psalms.

verses.text: They replied, 'The Lord Himself, living in heaven, commanded us to observe the seventh day.'
verses.comment: The Jews ground their obedience directly in the command of the living God, not mere human tradition. This underscores the divine authority of the commandments.

verses.text: At this, Nicanor responded, 'I am ruler upon the earth, and I command you to take up arms and carry out the king’s orders.' Yet he could not accomplish his plan.
verses.comment: Earthly rulers may command, but God's will remains ultimate. Compare with how God often frustrates the plans of the wicked (Prov. 21:30).

verses.text: Nicanor, in his arrogance, vowed to set up a public monument from the spoils of Judas and his followers after he had captured them.
verses.comment: Nicanor’s intention to boast in victory recalls the folly of the wicked who place trust in their own strength instead of God, as often depicted in the Psalms.

verses.text: But Maccabeus trusted absolutely that the Lord would provide him with help.
verses.comment: Judas Maccabeus exemplifies complete reliance on God, a profound Old Testament model of faith that resonates also in Christian confidence in divine providence.

verses.text: He encouraged his followers not to fear the attack of hostile nations, but to remember the help that had come before from Heaven, and to expect now as well the victory from the Almighty.
verses.comment: Judas points to God's past faithfulness as grounds for trusting in new deliverance, a theme repeated throughout salvation history.

verses.text: Encouraging them from the law and the prophets, and reminding them also of the struggles they had won, he made them the more eager.
verses.comment: The mention of Sennacherib refers to God miraculously saving Jerusalem; Judas encourages trust by recalling these historic acts of salvation.

verses.text: When he had aroused their courage, he issued his orders, at the same time pointing out the perfidy of the Gentiles and their violation of oaths.
verses.comment: The connection between suffering for faith and ultimate victory is taken up later by Christian martyrs (see Rom. 8:36).

verses.text: He ended his speech with encouragement, reminding them even of dreams that were worthy of trust, which could lift up the spirits of all.
verses.comment: Dreams in the Old Testament sometimes served as divine messages—Judas’s trust in such a dream implies openness to supernatural guidance.

verses.text: What he saw was this: Onias, the former high priest, a noble and good man, of modest bearing and gentle in speech, and trained from childhood in all that belongs to virtue, was praying with outstretched hands for the whole body of the Jews.
verses.comment: Onias, known for his holiness, is depicted as interceding for the people—even after death. This points to belief in the effectiveness of the prayers of the righteous who have gone before us (Jas. 5:16).

verses.text: Then there appeared to him a man distinguished by white hair and dignity, and remarkable for greatness and majesty.
verses.comment: The man’s appearance fits the Old Testament symbol of wisdom and authority, sometimes associated with heavenly beings or ancestors.

verses.text: Onias said, 'This is Jeremiah, the prophet of God, who loves his brothers and prays much for the people and the holy city.'
verses.comment: Jeremiah is depicted as interceding for Israel, showing a belief that the saints remain active in prayer for God's people—a biblical root for understanding the communion of saints.

verses.text: Jeremiah stretched out his right hand and gave Judas a golden sword, saying:
verses.comment: The sword is a symbol of divine aid and victory, which God gives to His faithful servants. It echoes angelic help in biblical battles.

verses.text: 'Take this holy sword, a gift from God; with it you will strike down your adversaries.'
verses.comment: The gift of the sword from a prophet, in a vision, embodies the idea that heavenly assistance is granted to those assigned to lead God’s people. The 'sword of the Spirit' in Ephesians draws from such imagery.

verses.text: Encouraged by these words of Judas, so noble and powerful, and strengthened in heart, the best of the young men were resolved not only to stand fast, but to attack courageously and fight bravely for religion, temple, city, country, and citizens.
verses.comment: This verse highlights the unity of religious, civic, and familial devotion, merging spiritual and earthly commitments as one.

verses.text: The great fear they had for the desecration of the holy temple was greater than fear for their wives or children, or even for their less holy relatives.
verses.comment: Devotion to God can require choosing Him above even family—a principle Christ later affirms (Luke 14:26).

verses.text: In the city, everyone was deeply anxious about the coming battle.
verses.comment: The looming battle grips the community, demonstrating the collective concern in spiritual warfare.

verses.text: And as the enemy was already drawing near, and the army deployed for battle, with the elephants arranged and the cavalry on the flanks, Maccabeus saw all these preparations and the boldness of his soldiers, and decided to rely on the Lord.
verses.comment: Despite the enemy’s military superiority, Judas’s faith looks beyond material resources—a pattern typical of biblical heroes.

verses.text: He encouraged his own men as well, not to fear the enemy; remembering the help from Heaven, he urged them to trust in the Lord's protection.
verses.comment: The reminder to trust God rather than chariots or horses parallels trusting divine power over human strength (cf. Ps. 20:7).

verses.text: With hands raised to heaven, he prayed to the Lord who works wonders, knowing that victory is not gained by weapons but as God chooses.
verses.comment: Dependence on God rather than weapons is a repeated message throughout the Old Testament; God accomplishes victory for His people.

verses.text: 'O Lord, you sent your angel under Hezekiah, king of Judah, who destroyed 185,000 men in the camp of Sennacherib. So now, O Sovereign of heaven, send a good angel before us to spread terror and dread.'
verses.comment: Judas’s prayer draws on the historic angelic intervention, seeking a similar divine deliverance. Angels repeatedly serve as God’s agents.

verses.text: 'By your mighty arm, destroy with the sword those who come with blasphemy against your holy people.' And with these words he ended his prayer.
verses.comment: Judas prays for God’s justice against blasphemers. Invoking divine judgment points to the seriousness of defending the Lord's honor.

verses.text: Nicanor and his army advanced to the sound of trumpets and war songs.
verses.comment: The enemy’s noisy display contrasts with Judas’s reliance on prayer and God's power.

verses.text: But the men of Judas met them, calling on God for help, as they engaged in battle.
verses.comment: Even in battle, prayer and martial action go together—a unity of faith and works. God responds to faith set in action.

verses.text: Fighting with their hands and praying to God in their hearts, they killed more than 35,000 of the enemy, rejoicing in God’s intervention.
verses.comment: Victory is attributed first to God, not man’s skill; salvation is the Lord’s work.

verses.text: When the battle was over and they were joyfully returning, they recognized Nicanor lying dead, clad in his armor.
verses.comment: God’s justice is manifest in the defeat of the blasphemer.

verses.text: Amidst shouts and tumult, they blessed the Lord in the language of their fathers.
verses.comment: Praise is offered to God in their traditional tongue, showing the importance of worshiping with inherited expressions of faith.

verses.text: Then Judas, who was always in body and soul devoted to his countrymen, ordered that Nicanor's head and right hand, which this arrogant man had lifted up against the holy house of God, should be cut off and displayed in Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Displaying the enemy's head echoes the defeat of Goliath, a sign of God’s faithfulness to defend His sanctuary.

verses.text: When he arrived there and had called his compatriots together and stationed the priests before the altar, he sent for those who were in the citadel.
verses.comment: Instituting a yearly remembrance shows the biblical foundation of sacred feasts for God’s saving acts. The importance of liturgical memory is highlighted.

verses.text: He showed them the vile Nicanor’s head and that profane man’s arm, which had been boastfully stretched out against the holy house of the Almighty.
verses.comment: The specific dating echoes that of Purim, revealing God’s providence through ordered remembrance.

verses.text: He cut out the tongue of the ungodly Nicanor and said that he would feed it piecemeal to the birds and would hang up these rewards of his folly opposite the sanctuary.
verses.comment: The public display underscores God’s triumph over blasphemers, testifying to all what God has accomplished.

verses.text: And they all, together, gave glory to the Lord in heaven, saying, 'Blessed is he who has kept his sacred place undefiled.'
verses.comment: Glorifying God for protecting His holy place prepares for the New Testament portrayal of Christ as the true Temple (John 2:19-21).

verses.text: Judas hung Nicanor’s head from the citadel, a clear and conspicuous sign to everyone of the help of the Lord.
verses.comment: Judas’s leadership is marked by God’s favor, a biblical example of godly governance.

verses.text: And they all decreed by public vote never to let this day go unobserved, but to celebrate the thirteenth day of the twelfth month — which is called Adar in the Aramaic language — the day before Mordecai’s day.
verses.comment: Liturgical commemorations reflect the biblical tradition of memorial feasts. Linking it to Purim ties these events into the larger salvation narrative.

verses.text: Thus, I will here bring my story to an end. If it has been told well, that is what I desired. If poorly, that was all I could do.
verses.comment: The humility of the narrator recalls other biblical writers who entrust their limited efforts to God’s mercy.

verses.text: For as wine blends well with water, so too does this story gain approval when it is composed skillfully, but if it is simple and ordinary, it is as I have been able.
verses.comment: The comparison to mixing wine and water reflects the belief that the communication of spiritual truths can take a humanly humble form.

verses.text: For just as it is harmful to drink wine alone, or, again, to drink water alone, while wine mixed with water is sweet and delicious and enhances one’s enjoyment, so also the style of the story delights the ears of those who read the work. And here will be the end.
verses.comment: The final request for gratitude and forgiveness is an invitation to receive this inspired history with humility and charity, opening the reader to its spiritual profit.
